abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Basic Health Care
            Project for Mexico were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, project sustainability was likely, Bank
            performance was satisfactory, and Borrower performance was
            deficient. Some lessons learned included: the institutional
            capacity of executing agencies at all levels has to be
            assessed carefully at appraisal and incorporated into
            project design, implementation and disbursement schedules.
            Baseline and follow-up surveys are essential in order to
            measure credibly project outcome. Project flexibility is
            essential to accommodate revisions in project design and
            priorities, as well as changes in the political environment;
            additionally, the rigidity of the rules and procedures of
            the national implementing agencies is often a formidable
            obstacle for smooth implementation. Even with a strong
            commitment by the Borrower, problems will arise if sector
            agencies do not share a sense of project ownership; projects
            may be reformulated and personnel arbitrarily moved,
            resulting in efficiency losses. The initial lack of project
            ownership by the ministry of health proved to be one of the
            largest constraints in project implementation. Decentralized
            procurement and investment planning requires a high level of
            local management capacity but results in a greater sense of
            ownership in the states, more appropriate planning, faster
            procurement and a more timely release of funds.
